awd_titl_txt: HDR TRIPODS: Collaborative Research: Institute for Data, Econometrics, Algorithms and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The Institute for Data, Econometrics, Algorithms, and Learning (IDEAL) is a multi-discipline (computer science, statistics, economics, electrical engineering, and operations research) and multi-institution (Northwestern University, Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago, and University of Chicago) collaborative institute that focuses on key aspects of the theoretical foundations of data science.   The institute will support the study of foundational problems related to machine learning, high-dimensional data analysis and optimization in both strategic and non-strategic environments.  The primary activity of the institute will be thematically focused quarters which will coordinate graduate course work with workshops and external visitors.  The institute will facilitate collaboration between Chicago-area institutions through a number of initiatives, and across multiple disciplines. Several components of the research agenda have direct applications areas, and the PIs will involve practitioners in development economics, online markets, public policy, as well as data scientists.   

The research areas supported by the institute focus on three broad themes:  (1) High dimensional data analysis, to address algorithmic and statistical challenges in dealing with high dimensional data, and investigate topics like metric embeddings, sketching, and problems in unsupervised learning; (2) Data Science in Strategic Environments, to address computational and information theoretic challenges in econometric models of strategic behavior like inference on high-dimensional structural parameter spaces,  dealing with unobserved heterogeneity, partial identification, and machine learning in econometrics; and (3) Machine learning and optimization, to address foundational questions in both continuous and discrete optimization and its use in machine learning including topics like representation learning, robustness in learning, and provable bounds for non-convex optimization.   Initially, six research topics will be selected that tie interests across the institutions: inference and data science on networks; theory of deep learning; incentives in shared data infrastructure; robustness in high-dimensional statistics; high-dimensional data analysis; and algorithms for partially identified models.  There will be special quarters (fall and spring) where the Institute will bring together investigators, postdocs, and Ph.D. students to focus on one of the topics.  In the following quarter (winter and summer) teams will continue research that advance the proposal topics.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project launched the Institute for Data, Econometrics, Algorithms, and Learning (IDEAL) as a multi-disciplinary (computer science, statistics, economics, electrical engineering, and operations research) and multi-institution (Northwestern University, Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago, and University of Chicago) collaborative institute that focused on key aspects of the theoretical foundations of data science. The institute supported the study of foundational problems related to machine learning, high-dimensional data analysis and optimization in both strategic and non-strategic environments. The institute facilitated collaboration between the different Chicago-area institutions through a number of activities and initiatives. 

 

Many of these activities centered around special quarters (in Fall and Spring) that were thematically focused on a specific aspect of data science foundations. There were six special quarters:

  1. Inference and data science on networks (Spring 2020)

  2. Deep Learning Theory (Fall 2020) 

  3. CS and Law (Spring 2021) 

  4. Robustness in Data Science (Fall 2021) 

  5. High-dimensional data analysis (Spring 2022) 

  6. Data Economics (Fall 2022)  

These special quarters included coordinated graduate coursework, workshops, and other joint activities like reading groups that led to initiation of research projects. Two postdoctoral research fellows were also trained and mentored as part of this project; they also helped in organizing many of these activities. The special quarters also led to many inter-disciplinary research projects. Most of the research produced were on along three broad themes: (1) High dimensional data analysis, that addressed algorithmic and statistical challenges in dealing with high dimensional data, like metric embeddings, sketching, and problems in unsupervised learning; (2) Data Science in Strategic Environments, that tackled address computational and information theoretic challenges in econometric models of strategic behavior like inference on high-dimensional structural parameter spaces, dealing with unobserved heterogeneity, partial identification, and machine learning in econometrics; and (3) Machine learning and optimization, that addressed foundational questions in both continuous and discrete optimization and its use in machine learning including topics like representation learning, robustness in learning, and provable bounds for non-convex optimization. Some research highlights from this project include new algorithms with provable guarantees for learning depth-2 neural networks (Awasthi et al., NeurIPS ’21), understanding benign overfitting in neural networks (Koehler et al., NeurIPS 2021), research on fairness (Blum et al., FAccT 2022, Makarychev et al., COLT 2022, Ahmadi et al., ICML 2022) in machine learning and algorithms. 

 

The project also helped develop new interdisciplinary research areas and directions in the foundations of data science. One highlight is the line of research that arose from the institute’s activities in the emerging new research area at the intersection of law, data science and computer science.  In Spring 2021 we had the IDEAL special quarter on Data Science and Law that included three half-day workshops and the launching of CS 497: The Science of Law and Computation, a new class for CS PhD students. The workshops and class were held virtually due to COVID-19 restrictions. Recordings of the workshops have been made available on the IDEAL website. There were at least three papers that directly came out of research initiated during this special quarter – two of them were published in the biennial ACM CS and Law conference 2022, and another followup project that also includes PhD student Liren Shan was accepted to CS and Law conference 2024. One of the research works (Dong et al., CSLAW 2022) designed multi-party classification protocols with minimal disclosure, that are  motivated by applications such as e-discovery in court proceedings. We identified a protocol that guarantees that the requesting party  receives all responsive documents and the sending party discloses the minimal amount of non-responsive documents necessary to prove that all responsive documents have been received. Another work (Hartline et al., CSLAW 2022) looked at a common law legal system as a machine learning algorithm, models specific features of legal proceedings, and asks whether this system learns efficiently. 

 

 The PIs also organized activities and workshops with the goal of reaching out to the broader scientific community interested in topics related to the project. Many of these events were either virtual or hybrid, since the majority of the project was during the COVID pandemic shutdowns. The workshops also often involved practitioners in development economics, online markets, public policy, as well as data scientists.We had a virtual institute over gather.town, and our online events got broad attendance from faculty, postdocs and students across the country (more than 50% were from outside IDEAL), and some even from outside the US. The research output from the institute have been published in several conferences and journals for dissemination, and in publicly accessible repositories like ArXiv. Videos of all of the seminar talks and workshop talks have been made available publicly on the IDEAL website (https://www.ideal.northwestern.edu/).
